importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding event occurred over a period of one week, with peak rainfall and impacts reported on Wednesday, indicating a short but intense weather event.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to flooding from heavy rains affecting five states.
The death toll includes 29 in Veracruz, 21 in Hidalgo, 13 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
Another 65 people are still missing, with the highest numbers in Hidalgo (43), Veracruz (18), and Puebla (4).
The heavy rainfall was caused by remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rain was recorded in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm respectively.
Thousands of military personnel, including Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to deliver food, clean water, and aid to affected areas.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply to 263,000 affected users across the five states.
Approximately 100,000 houses have been severely affected, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, confirmed the death and missing counts during President Claudia Sheinbaumâ€™s daily briefing.
President Claudia Sheinbaum acknowledged that no prior meteorological signs warned of such extreme rainfall, raising questions about warning systems and preparedness.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mexico has suffered severe flooding in five states due to heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The worst-hit areas are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths), with significant damage to infrastructure, including over 100,000 homes affected and some near rivers completely destroyed. The Mexican military and civil protection agencies have coordinated emergency responses, including delivering food and water, and restoring over 80% of electricity. The government acknowledged that no prior warning signs indicated the extreme rainfall, raising concerns about disaster preparedness and early alert systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
